How is it ethical at all to take a 𝟔𝟎% 𝐟𝐞𝐞 from these transactions!
for comparison, ebay takes 10%, upwork takes 23%
Oh, let us not forget,
“Fiverr takes its name from the $5 asking price attached to all tasks when the company was founded in 2010 in Tel Aviv”
So their USP was originally this. I mean they’ve capitalised a lot with these small transactions
reply_text:
roasted_banana:
The seller listed his price as $5. Fiverr puts a $2 fee to that. In the end fiverr earns 60% of $5. Why are people having such a long conversation on this lmao.
No, they don’t. Once again, your math is incorrect. The fee is not part of the $5 cost. This is why a buyer pays $7 for a $5 gig. $5 gig + $2 fee = $7.
Fiverr is still earning only 20% of the gig cost, taken out of the seller’s earnings (i.e., $1, in the case of a $5 gig). The $2 buyer fee will be the same, on every order price up to $40. Please take a moment, and actually listen to what the people in this topic are tell you.

reply_text:
The $2 buyer fee goes to Fiverr to cover administration costs. This is perfectly reasonable.
Fiverr, is, does, and will always only keep only 20% of the total gig purchase cost from the seller’s earnings. Fiverr never keeps more than 20%. The seller always keeps the remaining 80%. I don’t understand why this concept is so hard to understand. Sellers agree to a profit-sharing model where Fiverr keeps 20% of the gig cost, and the buyer keeps the remaining 80%. This is a flat sharing model.
Every buyer pays an additional administration fee of $2 on every up-to $40 order price, and if the order price goes over $40, the buyer pays an added 5% of the cost.
This seems pretty simple, direct, and fair to me.
If you don’t think it’s fair, then you don’t have to purchase services here. You have that choice.

reply_text:
While I do think Fiverr has a lot of fees, I also understand that they have a large infrastructure to support both buyer & seller (and there shareholders who deserve to be paid for their investment that keeps this whole balloon floating).
Why a Buyer should complain as tho they are being uniquely disadvantaged when they have to support that platform I am not sure. Sellers are supporting it very heavily too.
Fiverr are most likely trying to encourage people away from peanut jobs as while they seem attractive, they encourage poor outcomes not only in terms on income but quality of work. This is mostly likely the greatest cause for negativity around the whole online freelancer thing.
Instead of scrimping and thinking how clever you are to get all that work done (often poorly) for $5, see how much better it would be to get better results if you invested $50. Not only will your seller be more invested in getting you better results, but you get those better results and better loyalty. This is how good businesses are built. Nickle & dime-ing is a path to ruin.

reply_text:
The trick is to not use direct deposit.
Either use PayPal (no fees for me) or wait for a bunch of orders to finish approval before you withdraw.
The fee for direct deposit is $1, and that can now be negated since you get $4 instead.
Fiverr overall takes 42.857% of the money involved.
Math: 100 - [ ( 4 / 7 ) * 100 ] = 42.85714
If you make a ten dollar order (which is a lot more common honestly):
100 - [ ( 8 / 12 ) * 100 ] = 33.333…
Or fifteen:
100 - [ ( 12 / 17 ) * 100 ] = 29.41176
If you create a formula to find the percentage taken at large numbers (Including the 5% interest above $40):
lim_n 100 - { [ 4n / (( 5n + 2 ) + ( 0.5 * 5n ) ] * 100 }
Plug this in as the value n approaches infinity, and you find a trend:
lim_n-> inf = 23.80953
ISpentTooMuchTimeOnThis
1394×664 67.4 KB
I seriously spent way too much time calculating that, but Fiverr’s “20% cut” is almost exact, the only difference is the 5% charge on orders $40 or more.

Another way to look at it is from Fiverr’s perspective.
image
540×512 7.6 KB
gina_riley2:
Frankly, from a business perspective, I can see 5r’s POV. By raising the admin/transaction fees, they are doing two things:
Cost of doing business for lower cost clients will equal out to higher cost buyers
Encourages people to buy higher cost gigs
It worked, because I don’t buy any gigs under $20 these days. Most of the time, I buy gigs priced at $40 & more.
Because of (2), Fiverr earns more on those higher value orders.
This is a good business strategy.

maitasun:
Nope, Gina is right! The total cost of the order is $7: $5 for the order + $2 of the buyer’s fee.
No. The order value doesn’t include the service fee. That’s not the order value. The order value remains as $5.
@roasted_banana isn’t saying that Fiverr gets 60% of what the buyer pays, rather 60% of the order value.
If you get a $5 order, what’s the big number at the top of the order page? It isn’t $7, for what the buyer pays. It isn’t $4, for what you get in the end. It’s $5, because $5 remains the order value despite additional fees.

reply_text:
Okay, there is a difference in perceived value, numeric value, and utility value. If you’re using different terminology, then yes, you’ll be coming up with different numbers.
en.wikipedia.org
Value (economics)
In economics, economic value is a measure of the benefit provided by a good or service to an economic agent. It is generally measured relative to units of currency, and the interpretation is therefore "what is the maximum amount of money a specific actor is willing and able to pay for the good or service"? Among the competing schools of economic theory there are differing theories of value. Economic value is not the same as market price, nor is economic value the same thing as market value. If ...
en.wikipedia.org
Utility
Within economics, the concept of utility is used to model worth or value. Its usage has evolved significantly over time. The term was introduced initially as a measure of pleasure or satisfaction within the theory of utilitarianism by moral philosophers such as Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill. The term has been adapted and reapplied within neoclassical economics, which dominates modern economic theory, as a utility function that represents a consumer's preference ordering over a choice set....
If you use the numeric value, then the [total cost to the buyer] is $7, for which Fiverr gets $3 and the Seller gets $4.
From a Seller perspective, I always get 80% of my listed price. Always. What Fiverr gets is Fiverr’s business (figuratively and literally). What the buyer pays is completely dependent on their (objective?subjective?) perspective of “is the total input (cost) worth the output?”, which is my business. But it’s also my business to make sure my product/service is worth that total cost.
Now, that “value”, I can understand why a buyer might be upset.
From a buyer perspective, I’m getting short-changed. The ‘total’ value doesn’t match the ‘perceived’ value.
Huh.
There might be a bit of a valid point in this.
Excuse me while I go do some cost/benefit stuff and maybe preparation work to raise my prices a bit more.

thread_name: I deleted all my gigs and started from scratch
thread_text:
I made a drastic decision as the year began - I decided to delete all my gigs and created new ones. I had read of the dangers of taking this route but I felt I needed to. So, this is me sharing my experience in case there is someone out there wondering if they should recreate their gigs or just keep editing them.
When I joined Fiverr as a seller, I wasn’t sure which services to offer so I started of as a jack of all trades. But after a while, I quickly niched down and edited my old gigs to represent that. The only problem was I now had gig URLS that told a totally different story from the gig description. And that bothered me so much that I decided to recreate them.
I was on pins and needles because I didn’t know how this experiment would turn out. But after a couple of months, I have no regrets. Here is what I have learned so far from the experiment;
I am getting almost the same number of impressions but at least I am getting the right traffic
My income has improved. But I think this is because I raised my rates.
I am no longer attracting requests from random clients who are not interested in the services I am offering.
I have no way of proving this but I suspect my conversions would be better if I had more reviews
*I had to depend on returning clients at first before my new gigs started ranking again. I also had to let go of some old clients in order to focus on one niche.
So I guess it is safe to say that deleting your gigs to recreate them can be a good thing. But only do this if you really need to change the gig URL. Also, do your own cost-benefit analysis because it could potentially affect your sales
reply_text: N/A

thread_name: Hello Ghost writers, please help me out
thread_text:
I have had many clients asking me for proof of my ghost writing work. Unfortunately, once I deliver my work, I give all the rights pertaining the book to the author or the client. I see the need to prove to new clients that I am good at writing auto bios and memoirs, but how do I do this without infringing on the privacy of the already existing clients? I tried asking for permission but the ones I have worked with so far are not comfortable with that arrangement.
Someone please advice
reply_text: This post was flagged by the community and is temporarily hidden.

thread_text: Hi, I have completed my work, but as per my routine practice, I let my buyer check whether it is according to his requirements or not, once he OKs, I deliver. Usually, I finished my work within hours but still, I let my buyer respond first before delivering. Now since yesterday my buyer is not responding and my delivery is more than 1 hour late, what should I do, (I requested the extension but buyer is still not responding). Plus tell me will it effect my profile or gig negatively.
reply_text: You should deliver your order once it gets done and not wait for the response instead. Remember that you can always provide them with revisions. And yes your profile and chances of evaluation shall get affected you deliver you orders late

reply_text: One of my friends said, delivering late within 4 hours wont effect anything as it’s a buffer time, do you know any such thing?

thread_text: Hi, I have completed my work, but as per my routine practice, I let my buyer check whether it is according to his requirements or not, once he OKs, I deliver. Usually, I finished my work within hours but still, I let my buyer respond first before delivering. Now since yesterday my buyer is not responding and my delivery is more than 1 hour late, what should I do, (I requested the extension but buyer is still not responding). Plus tell me will it effect my profile or gig negatively.
reply_text:
It still counts as a late delivery.
I let my buyer check
Have you been sending finished work via messages? You should only ever send finished work with the deliver option. As someone else said, if the buyer wants any changes then they can request a revision. There’s no reason to put yourself at risk of delivering late.

thread_text: Hi, I have completed my work, but as per my routine practice, I let my buyer check whether it is according to his requirements or not, once he OKs, I deliver. reply_text: Never do that. It would be very easy for a buyer to take that work and and cancel the order - meaning they get your work for free. It’s not worth the risk.

reply_text: Ok, but he is a returning buyer, maybe this time something happened to him.

thread_text: Hi, I have completed my work, but as per my routine practice, I let my buyer check whether it is according to his requirements or not, once he OKs, I deliver. Usually, I finished my work within hours but still, I let my buyer respond first before delivering. Now since yesterday my buyer is not responding and my delivery is more than 1 hour late, what should I do, (I requested the extension but buyer is still not responding). Plus tell me will it effect my profile or gig negatively.
reply_text:
Or they are busy. I’m not saying this particular one is trying to scam you, just that you’re making it very easy for people to do.
Deliver the work with the deliver button. Revisions exist for a reason - you’ll just have to accept that this particular order is going to be marked as a late delivery.
On that note, I recommend you stop offering unlimited revisions. All that does is attract bad buyers.

thread_text: Hi, I have completed my work, but as per my routine practice, I let my buyer check whether it is according to his requirements or not, once he OKs, I deliver. Usually, I finished my work within hours but still, I let my buyer respond first before delivering. Now since yesterday my buyer is not responding and my delivery is more than 1 hour late, what should I do, (I requested the extension but buyer is still not responding). Plus tell me will it effect my profile or gig negatively.
reply_text:
You must never send completed work in a message - regardless of whether you trust the buyer or not. Simply deliver the order, and if the client wants a revision then they request that through Fiverr. Buyers requesting a revision is perfectly normal practice, and as far as I know does not affect your seller stats in any way.
As for delivering up to four hours late not affecting your stats, that is a load of rubbish. One second late and it will be recorded as a late delivery.
